https://trustmark.gtri.gatech.edu/operational-pilot/trustmark-definitions/ficam-loa-2-tokens-requirements/1.0/ https://trustmark.gtri.gatech.edu/operational-pilot/trustmark-definitions/ficam-loa-2-tokens-requirements/1.0/trustmark-reference/ FICAM LOA 2 Tokens Requirements 1.0 This Trustmark Definition adopts the LOA 2 Tokens trust criteria of the FICAM Trust Framework Provider Adoption Process. 2014-10-07T09:57:01 https://trustmark.gtri.gatech.edu/ Georgia Tech Research Institute PRIMARY TrustmarkFeedback@gtri.gatech.edu 404-407-8956 75 5th Street NW, Suite 900, Atlanta, GA 30308 Stakeholders of the U.S. federal notions of levels of assurance as defined by the National Institute of Standards and Technology and the FICAM TFS. Credential Service Providers that wish to assert identities to either federal relying parties or relying parties that utilize the U.S. federal notions of levels of assurance. U.S. federal relying parties and other relying parties that utilize the U.S. federal notions of levels of assurance. Current or prospective FICAM-approved trust framework providers (TFPs), or Trustmark Providers that specialize in assessments concerning the U.S. federal notions of levels of assurance.

Any organization or business entity may act as a Trustmark Provider for trustmarks under this Trustmark Definition.

]]>

Any individual employed or contracted by the Trustmark Provider may act as the assessor for trustmarks under this Trustmark Definition.

]]>

For any trustmark issued under this Trustmark Definition, the Trustmark Provider must revoke the trustmark upon any condition whereby one or more Conformance Criteria cease to be satisfied.

]]>

This Trustmark Definition requires no extension data.

]]> This document and the information contained herein is provided on an "AS IS" basis, and the Georgia Tech Research Institute disclaims all warranties, express or implied, including but not limited to any warranty that the use of the information herein will not infringe any rights or any implied warranties or merchantability or fitness for a particular purpose. In addition, the Georgia Tech Research Institute disclaims legal liability for any loss incurred as a result of the use or reliance on the document or the information contained herein. The Georgia Tech Research Institute (GTRI) has published this document with the support of the National Strategy for Trusted Identities in Cyberspace (NSTIC) via the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST). The views expressed herein do not necessarily reflect the official policies of GTRI, NIST or NSTIC; nor does mention of trade names, commercial practices, or organizations imply endorsement by the U.S. Government. adopted authentication scheme / adopted scheme An open identity management standard that the ICAM assesses, approves, and scopes for use across the federal government. An adopted scheme meets all applicable ICAM requirements, as well as other federal statutes, regulations, and policies. In addition, the structured adoption process provides assurance to all ICAM participants that underlying identity assurance technologies are appropriate, robust, reliable, and secure.

]]> applicant A party undergoing the processes of registration and identity proofing.

]]> approved cryptographic method FIPS approved or NIST recommend. An algorithm or technique that is either (1) specified in a FIPS or NIST Recommendation, or (2) adopted in a FIPS or NIST Recommendation.

]]> authentication assertion A statement from a verifier to an RP that may contain identity and attribute information about a subscriber, as well as information about an authentication event that has been completed with the subscriber.

]]> authentication factor A category of tokens that is either "something you know" (e.g., a password), "something you have" (e.g., a cryptographic key), or "something you are" (e.g., a fingerprint).

]]> authentication protocol / authentication scheme A defined sequence of messages between a claimant and a verifier that demonstrates that the claimant has possession and control of a valid token to establish his/her identity, and optionally, demonstrates to the claimant that he or she is communicating with the intended verifier. An authentication protocol may also define the generation of an authentication assertion to be provided to an RP.

]]> authentication protocol run An exchange of messages between a claimant and a verifier that executes an authentication protocol and results in authentication, or authentication failure, between the two parties.

]]> claimant A party whose identity is to be verified using an authentication protocol.

]]> credential An object or data structure that authoritatively binds an identity (and optionally, additional attributes) to a token possessed and controlled by a subscriber. A credential may be maintained by the subscriber to which the credential was issued or by the CSP that issued the credential.

]]> credential service provider CSP An entity that issues or registers subscriber tokens and issues credentials to subscribers (i.e, a CSP conducts the issuance process). A CSP may encompass RAs and verifiers that it operates. A CSP may be an independent third party, or may issue credentials for its own use.

]]> established policy, procedure, or practice statement A policy, procedure, or practice statement that has been formally adopted and put into use by an entity.

]]> established technical capability The ability to accurately implement and maintain, as part of normal business operations, a technical mechanism for achieving some goal.

]]> external RA designee An RA designee that is governed by an entity other than the CSP that it serves.

]]> external verifier designee A verifier designee that is governed by an entity other the CSP that it serves.

]]> Federal Identity, Credential, and Access Management FICAM An initiative for implementing ICAM principles within the U.S. Federal Government.

]]> Federal Identity, Credential, and Access Management Trust Framework Solutions FICAM TFS The federated identity framework for the U.S. Federal Government.

]]> Identity, Credential, and Access Management ICAM A federal program that focuses on addressing challenges, pressing issues, and design requirements for digital identity, credential, and access management and defining and promoting consistency across approaches for implementing ICAM programs as reflected in the FICAM Roadmap & Implementation Guidance

]]> Identity, Credential, and Access Management Sub-Committee ICAMSC A committee established in 2008 under the Federal CIO Council's Information Security and Identity Management Committee (ISIMC) and tasked with aligning the identity management activities of the Federal Government..

]]> identity proofing The process by which a CSP and an RA collect and verify information about a person for the purpose of issuing credentials to that person.

]]> identity provider IDP A system used to perform the token / credential validation functions of a CSP and the authentication and assertion issuance functions of a verifier.

]]> issuance The process of issuing tokens or credentials to a subscriber of a CSP.

]]> level of assurance LOA The degree of confidence in the vetting process used to establish the identity of an individual to whom the credential was issued and the degree of confidence that the individual who uses the credential is the individual to whom the credential was issued. Also, see the use of assurance in [OMB M-04-04].

]]> LOA 2 level of assurance 2. As defined in [OMB M-04-04], LOA 2 means "Some confidence in an asserted identity's validity". This is in contrast to levels 1, 3, and 4, which mean "little or no", "high", and "very high", respectively, in regards to assurance in an asserted identity's validity.

]]> LOA 2 adopted authentication scheme An adopted authentication scheme approved for use at LOA 2.

]]> LOA 2 applicant An applicant that has applied to go through an LOA 2 registration and issuance process sequence.

]]> LOA 2 authentication assertion An authentication assertion that is intended to conform to LOA 2 requirements.

]]> LOA 2 authentication protocol An authentication protocol that is intended to conform to LOA 2 requirements.

]]> LOA 2 credential A credential that that is intended to conform to LOA 2 requirements.

]]> LOA 2 identity proofing An identity proofing process that is intended to conform to LOA 2 requirements.

]]> LOA 2 issuance An issuance process that is intended to conform to LOA 2 requirements.

]]> LOA 2 registration A registration process that is intended to conform to LOA 2 requirements.

]]> LOA 2 registration and issuance A sequence of registration and issuance processes that is intended to conform to LOA 2 requirements.

]]> LOA 2 shared secret file A shared secret file that is intended to conform to LOA 2 requirements.

]]> LOA 2 subscriber A subscriber that has gone through a LOA 2 registration and issuance process sequence.

]]> LOA 2 token A token that is intended to conform to LOA 2 requirements.

]]> LOA 2 token authenticator A token authenticator generated by an LOA 2 token.

]]> LOA 3 level of assurance 3. As defined in [OMB M-04-04], LOA 3 means "high confidence in an asserted identity's validity". This is in contrast to levels 1, 2, and 4, which mean "little or no", "some", and "very high", respectively, in regards to assurance in an asserted identity's validity.

]]> LOA 3 adopted authentication scheme An adopted authentication scheme approved for use at LOA 3.

]]> LOA 3 applicant An applicant that has applied to go through an LOA 3 registration and issuance process sequence.

]]> LOA 3 authentication assertion An authentication assertion that is intended to conform to LOA 3 requirements.

]]> LOA 3 authentication protocol An authentication protocol that is intended to conform to LOA 3 requirements.

]]> LOA 3 credential A credential that that is intended to conform to LOA 3 requirements.

]]> LOA 3 identity proofing An identity proofing process that is intended to conform to LOA 3 requirements.

]]> LOA 3 issuance An issuance process that is intended to conform to LOA 3 requirements.

]]> LOA 3 registration A registration process that is intended to conform to LOA 3 requirements.

]]> LOA 3 registration and issuance A sequence of registration and issuance processes that is intended to conform to LOA 3 requirements.

]]> LOA 3 shared secret file A shared secret file that is intended to conform to LOA 3 requirements.

]]> LOA 3 subscriber A subscriber that has gone through a LOA 3 registration and issuance process sequence.

]]> LOA 3 token A token that is intended to conform to LOA 3 requirements.

]]> LOA 3 token authenticator A token authenticator generated by an LOA 3 token.

]]> multi-factor token A token that uses two or more factors to achieve authentication.

]]> multi-stage authentication An authentication scheme, or series of authentication schemes used together, in which one token is used to obtain a second token.

]]> multi-token authentication An authentication scheme in which the claimant presents token authenticators generated by two or more tokens (not using a multi-stage process) to prove his or her identity to the verifier. The combination of tokens is characterized by the combination of factors used by the tokens (both inherent in the manifestation of the tokens, and those used to activate the tokens).

]]> NIST National Institute of Standards and Technology.

]]> OMB United States Office of Management and Budget.

]]> personally identifiable information PII Information which can be used to distinguish or trace an individual's identity, such as their name, social security number, biometric records, etc. alone, or when combined with other personal or identifying information which is linked or linkable to a specific individual, such as date and place of birth, mother's maiden name, etc.

]]> policy A statement of criteria to which an entity is expected to conform.

]]> practice statement A formal statement of the practices followed by a party. A practice statement usually describes the policies and practices of the party and can become legally binding.

]]> procedure A sequence of steps that achieves some stated goal.

]]> process See "procedure"

]]> RA designee An RA designated by a particular CSP to conduct LOA 2 registration or LOA 2 identity proofing processes on behalf of that CSP. An RA designee may be governed directly by the relying CSP (e.g., a department or business unit of the CSP), or by an entity external to the relying CSP.

]]> registration authority RA An entity that establishes and vouches for the identity or attributes of a subscriber to a CSP. The RA may be an integral part of a CSP, or it may be independent of a CSP, but it has a relationship to the CSP(s). It is important for an RA to be trusted by the CSPs and applicants that it serves and RPs that rely on the identity proofing that it does.

]]> registration and issuance The sequence of the registration and issuance processes.

]]> registration The process through which an applicant applies to become a subscriber of a CSP and an RA validates the identity of the applicant on behalf of the CSP. In other words, registration includes identity proofing and refers to the registration by an RA of the results of performing identity proofing on an applicant.

]]> relying party RP An entity that relies upon a subscriber's credentials or verifier's assertion of an identity, typically to process a transaction or grant access to an information system.

]]> shared secret A secret used in authentication that is known to the claimant and the verifier.

]]> shared secret file A file held by a CSP or verifier that contains secrets held between the CSP or verifier and its subscribers or claimants.

]]> single-factor token A token that uses one of the three factors to achieve authentication.

]]> single-token authentication An authentication scheme in which the claimant presents a single token authenticator to prove his or her identity to the verifier.

]]> subscriber A party who has received a credential or token from a CSP.

]]> TFPAP Trust Framework Provider Adoption Process, v2.0.2. See [TFPAP].

]]> token Something that a claimant possess and controls (typically a cryptographic module or password) that is used to authenticate the claimant's identity.

]]> token authenticator The output value generated by a token. This value is one that is provided to a protocol stack to prove that a claimant possess and controls a token. Protocol messages sent to a verifier are dependent upon the token authenticator, but may or may not explicitly contain it.

]]> verifier An entity that verifies a claimant's identity by verifying the claimant's possession and control of a token using an authentication protocol. To do this, the verifier may also need to validate credentials that link the token and identity and check their status.

]]> verifier designee A verifier designated by a particular CSP to conduct LOA 2 authentication protocol run processes on behalf of that CSP. A verifier designee may be governed by the CSP (e.g., a department or business unit of the CSP), or by an entity external to the CSP.

]]> SP 800-63-2 NIST SP 800-63-2: Electronic Authentication Guideline, August, 2013 OMB M-04-04 Office of Management and Budget Memorandum M-04-04, December 16, 2003 TFPAP LOA 2 FICAM TFS Trust Framework Provider Adoption Process for All Levels of Assurance, v2.0.2, March, 14, 2014, Appendix A-2: Assurance Level 2 1 Resist token theft The CSP must ensure that physical LOA 2 tokens are protected from being stolen by an attacker; i.e., the CSP must resist the threat of theft of physical LOA 2 tokens.

]]> Tokens Table, Item 1]]> Section 6: Tokens]]> 2 Resist token duplication The CSP must ensure that LOA 2 tokens are protected from being copied by an attacker; i.e., the CSP must resist the threat of duplication of LOA 2 tokens.

]]> Tokens Table, Item 2]]> Section 6: Tokens]]> 3 Resist social engineering The CSP must ensure the protection against an LOA 2 subscriber being convinced to reveal issued LOA 2 tokens or issued LOA 2 token secrets to an attacker; i.e., the CSP must resist the threat of social engineering on holders of LOA 2 tokens.

]]> Tokens Table, Item 3]]> Section 6: Tokens]]> 4 Memorized secret tokens The CSP MUST ensure that the following requirements are met for each memorized secret LOA 2 token that it issues or registers.

  1. The token is a randomly generated personal identification number (PIN) that has entropy equivalent to a PIN consisting of six or more digits, or is a user generated string or secret that has entropy equivalent to eight or more characters chosen from an alphabet of 90 or more characters.

  2. The CSP MUST implement dictionary or composition rules to constrain user-generated secrets.

  3. The CSP's LOA 2 verifier designees implement a throttling mechanism that, for LOA 2 authentication process runs, effectively limits the number of failed authentication attempts an attacker can make on any LOA 2 subscriber's account to 100 or fewer in any 30 day period.

]]> Tokens Table, Item 4]]> Section 6: Tokens]]> 5 Pre-registered knowledge tokens The CSP MUST ensure that the following requirements are met for each pre-registered knowledge LOA 2 token that it issues or registers.

  1. The token has at least 20 bits of entropy.

  2. Empty secrets are prohibited and the entopy in every secret cannot be directly calculated.

  3. Knowledge questions are either supplied by the user or selected by the user from a set of at least seven questions.

  4. The CSP's LOA 2 verifier designees implement a throttling mechanism that, for LOA 2 authentication process runs, effectively limits the number of failed authentication attempts an attacker can make on any LOA 2 subscriber's account to 100 or fewer in any 30 day period.

]]> Tokens Table, Item 5]]> Section 6: Tokens]]> 6 Look-up secret tokens The MUST ensure that one of the following requirements are met for each look-up secret LOA 2 token that it issues or registers.

  1. Every token authenticator has at least 64 bits of entropy.

  2. Every token authenticator has at least 20 bits of entropy, and the CSP's LOA 2 verifier designees implement a throttling mechanism that, for LOA 2 authentication process runs, effectively limits the number of failed authentication attempts an attacker can make on any LOA 2 subscriber's account to 100 or fewer in any 30 day period.

]]> Tokens Table, Item 6]]> Section 6: Tokens]]> 7 Out-of-band tokens The CSP MUST ensure that the following requirements are met for each out-of-band LOA 2 token that it issues or registers.

  1. The token is uniquely addressable and supports communication over a channel that is separate from the primary channel for e-authentication.

  2. Every secret generated by every LOA 2 verifier designee of the CSP either has at least 64 bits of entropy, or has at least 20 bits of entropy and the CSP LOA 2 verifier designee that generated the secret implements a throttling mechanism that, for LOA 2 authentication process runs, effectively limits the number of failed authentication attempts an attacker can make on any LOA 2 subscriber's account to 100 or fewer in any 30 day period.

]]> Tokens Table, Item 7]]> Section 6: Tokens]]> 8 Single-factor one-time password device tokens The CSP MUST ensure that the following requirements are met for each single-factor one-time password device LOA 2 token that it issues or registers.

  1. Every device uses a block cipher or hash function, that is an approved cryptographic method, to combine a symmetric key stored on the device with a nonce to generate a one-time password.

  2. Every one-time password generated by every device has a limited lifetime, on the order of minutes.

  3. Every cryptographic module performing the verifier function is validated at FIPS 140-2 Level 1 or higher.

  4. Every device generates a nonce from either a date and time, or a counter generated on the device.

]]> Tokens Table, Item 8]]> Section 6: Tokens]]> 9 Single-factor cryptographic device tokens The CSP MUST ensure that the following requirements are met for each single-factor cryptographic device LOA 2 token that it issues or registers.

  1. Every cryptographic module is validated at FIPS 140-2 Level 1 or higher.

  2. Verifier-generated token input (e.g., nonce or challenge) has at least 64 bits of entropy.

]]> Tokens Table, Item 9]]> Section 6: Tokens]]> For assessment steps that require the verification that there are established policies or procedures that demonstrate conformance to a particular conformance criterion, there is an implied requirement to verify that there are no established policies or procedures that demonstrate non-conformance to that criterion. This can be facilitated by documenting references to sections of established policies and procedures that explicitly enumerate the entirety of the relevant items that need to be verified for conformance.

To answer an assessment step as not applicable, the assessor must document references to, and explanatory annotations of, sections of established policies or procedures of the Trustmark Applicant, its RA designees, or its CSP designees, that provide supporting evidence of why the assessment step should be answered as not applicable.

Assessors should use [SP 800-63-2 Tokens] as a guide for determining acceptable threat mitigation mechanisms.

When a multi-token authentication scheme is being used, the new level of assurance must be determined in accordance with NIST SP SP 800-63 Table 7. Using multiple tokens to achieve an increased level of assurance requires the use of two different factors of authentication. Combining multiple factors and/or multiple tokens may achieve a higher assurance level than would otherwise be attained. If one factor of a multi-factor scheme or one token of a multi-token scheme has the desired properties for a given assurance level, it is considered sufficient. LOA 3 can be achieved using two tokens rated at LOA 2 that represent two different authentication factors. Since the use of biometrics as a stand-alone token for remote authentication is not addressed, achieving LOA 3 with separate LOA 2 tokens requires the use of something you have and something you know.

Multi-stage authentication processes, which use a single-factor token to obtain a second token, must not constitute multi-factor authentication. The level of assurance associated with the compound solution is the assurance level of the weakest token.

See Appendix A of [SP 800-63-2] for a complete discussion on entropy.

]]> 1 Policy for resisting token theft Does the trustmark applicant have established policies or procedures that demonstrate that it resists the threat of token theft as required? Document references to sections of established policies and procedures that demonstrate conformance, and provide annotations that justify conformance.

]]> Annotated References Annotated references to the conforming sections of established policies and procedures.

]]> 2 Technical capabilities for resisting token theft Does the trustmark applicant have established technical capabilities that enable it to resist the threat of token theft as required? Evaluate and describe the relevant established technical capabilities.

]]> Technical Capabilities Documented evaluation and description of the conforming technical capabilities.

]]> 3 Policy for resisting token duplication Does the trustmark applicant have established policies or procedures that demonstrate it resists the threat of token duplication as required? Document references to sections of established policies and procedures that demonstrate conformance, and provide annotations that justify conformance.

]]> Annotated References Annotated references to the conforming sections of established policies and procedures.

]]> 4 Technical capabilities for resisting token duplication Does the trustmark applicant have established technical capabilities that enable it to resist the threat of token duplication as required? Evaluate and describe the relevant established technical capabilities.

]]> Technical Capabilities Documented evaluation and description of the conforming technical capabilities.

]]> 5 Policy for resisting social engineering Does the trustmark applicant have established policies or procedures that demonstrate it resists the threat of social engineering as required? Document references to sections of established policies and procedures that demonstrate conformance, and provide annotations that justify conformance.

]]> Annotated References Annotated references to the conforming sections of established policies and procedures.

]]> 6 Technical capabilities for resisting social engineering Does the trustmark applicant have established technical capabilities that enable it to resist the threat of social engineering as required? Evaluate and describe the relevant established technical capabilities.

]]> Technical Capabilities Documented evaluation and description of the conforming technical capabilities.

]]> 7 Policy for meeting requirements on memorized secret tokens Does the trustmark applicant have established policies or procedures that demonstrate it issues and registers memorized secret tokens as required? Document references to sections of established policies and procedures that demonstrate conformance, and provide annotations that justify conformance.

]]> Annotated References Annotated references to the conforming sections of established policies and procedures.

]]> 8 Technical capabilities for meeting requirements on memorized secret tokens Does the trustmark applicant have established technical capabilities that enable it to issue and register memorized secret tokens as required? Evaluate and describe the relevant established technical capabilities.

]]> Technical Capabilities Documented evaluation and description of the conforming technical capabilities.

]]> 9 Policy for meeting requirements on pre-registered knowledge tokens Does the trustmark applicant have established policies or procedures that demonstrate it issues and registers pre-registered knowledge tokens as required? Document references to sections of established policies and procedures that demonstrate conformance, and provide annotations that justify conformance.

]]> Annotated References Annotated references to the conforming sections of established policies and procedures.

]]> 10 Technical capabilities for meeting requirements on pre-registered knowledge tokens Does the trustmark applicant have established technical capabilities that enable it to issue and register pre-registered knowledge tokens as required? Evaluate and describe the relevant established technical capabilities.

]]> Technical Capabilities Documented evaluation and description of the conforming technical capabilities.

]]> 11 Policy for meeting requirements on look-up secret tokens Does the trustmark applicant have established policies or procedures that demonstrate it issues and registers look-up secret tokens as required? Document references to sections of established policies and procedures that demonstrate conformance, and provide annotations that justify conformance.

]]> Annotated References Annotated references to the conforming sections of established policies and procedures.

]]> 12 Technical capabilities for meeting requirements on look-up secret tokens Does the trustmark applicant have established technical capabilities that enable it to issue and register look-up secret tokens as required? Evaluate and describe the relevant established technical capabilities.

]]> Technical Capabilities Documented evaluation and description of the conforming technical capabilities.

]]> 13 Policy for meeting requirements on out-of-band tokens Does the trustmark applicant have established policies or procedures that demonstrate it issues and registers out-of-band tokens as required? Document references to sections of established policies and procedures that demonstrate conformance, and provide annotations that justify conformance.

]]> Annotated References Annotated references to the conforming sections of established policies and procedures.

]]> 14 Technical capabilities for meeting requirements on out-of-band tokens Does the trustmark applicant have established technical capabilities that enable it to issue and register out-of-band tokens as required? Evaluate and describe the relevant established technical capabilities.

]]> Technical Capabilities Documented evaluation and description of the conforming technical capabilities.

]]> 15 Policy for meeting requirements on single-factor one-time password device tokens Does the trustmark applicant have established policies or procedures that demonstrate it issues and registers single-factor one-time password device tokens as required? Document references to sections of established policies and procedures that demonstrate conformance, and provide annotations that justify conformance.

]]> Annotated References Annotated references to the conforming sections of established policies and procedures.

]]> 16 Technical capabilities for meeting requirements on single-factor one-time password device tokens Does the trustmark applicant have established technical capabilities that enable it to issue and register single-factor one-time password device tokens as required? Evaluate and describe the relevant established technical capabilities.

]]> Technical Capabilities Documented evaluation and description of the conforming technical capabilities.

]]> 17 Policy for meeting requirements on single-factor cryptographic device tokens Does the trustmark applicant have established policies or procedures that demonstrate it issues and registers single-factor cryptographic device tokens as required? Document references to sections of established policies and procedures that demonstrate conformance, and provide annotations that justify conformance.

]]> Annotated References Annotated references to the conforming sections of established policies and procedures.

]]> 18 Technical capabilities for meeting requirements on single-factor cryptographic device tokens Does the trustmark applicant have established technical capabilities that enable it to issue and register single-factor cryptographic device tokens as required? Evaluate and describe the relevant established technical capabilities.

]]> Technical Capabilities Documented evaluation and description of the conforming technical capabilities.

]]> yes(TokenTheftPolicy) and yes(TokenTheftTech) and yes(TokenDuplicationPolicy) and yes(TokenDuplicationTech) and yes(SocialEngPolicy) and yes(SocialEngTech) and !no(MemorizedSecretPolicy) and !no(MemorizedSecretTech) and !no(PreRegKnowledgePolicy) and !no(PreRegKnowledgeTech) and !no(LookUpSecretPolicy) and !no(LookUpSecretTech) and !no(OutOfBandPolicy) and !no(OutOfBandTech) and !no(SingleFactorOTPPolicy) and !no(SingleFactorOTPTech) and !no(SingleFactorCryptoPolicy) and !no(SingleFactorCryptoTech)
